issues.description: The problem statement requires the student function to create a new stack frame using the instruction `enter 0,0`, but neither the template nor the solution include this instruction. This is a cross-artifact mismatch: the specification enforces a calling-frame convention that the provided starter code and reference implementation do not follow. Students may be confused whether they must add `enter 0,0` (and where) or whether the requirement is optional; moreover, an automated Makefile or grader that expects that prologue could fail if the code does not include it.
issues.suggested_fix: Either remove or relax the explicit `enter 0,0` requirement from the problem statement (if it is not enforced by the grader), or update both the template and the solution to include the required stack-frame prologue (e.g., insert `enter 0,0` immediately after the function label in the template and solution). Also clarify in the problem text whether different assemblers/linkers expect alternative prologues.

issues.description: The template and the solution use different global entry labels: the template declares `global main` / `main:` while the solution declares `global CMAIN` / `CMAIN:`. This mismatch may confuse students about which symbol the build/Makefile and runtime expect and could cause students to change the wrong label or spend time debugging link/entry errors.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the entry symbol consistent across artifacts. Either update the template to use `CMAIN` (and note this in the problem statement / Makefile), or update the solution to use `main`. Additionally, document in the problem statement which global label the Makefile expects so students know which label to keep or modify.
